name.text: Finding the reciprocal of decimal numbers using a table of reciprocals

questiontext.text:
Use a table of reciprocals to find the reciprocal of {@a@}.

Give your answer to 4 decimal places.

Reciprocal of \({@a@} =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

To find the reciprocal of \({@a@}\) (which is \(\frac{1}{@a@}\)) using a mathematical table, follow the steps below.

1. In the table of reciprocals, move down the column labelled \(x\) until you locate the row {@float(part_a)@}.

2. From this row, move across to the main column headed {@part_b@}.

3. Read the number at the intersection of this row and column.
This value is {@a_1_answer@}.

4. Next, move further along the same row to the "SUBTRACT" column (Mean Difference) headed {@part_c@}.
The number you find here is the mean difference, which is {@sub_num@} (in the last decimal places).

5. Subtract this mean difference from your first value.
(Note: We subtract because the reciprocal function \(\frac{1}{x}\) decreases as \(x\) increases).

\[ {@a_1_answer@} - 0.000{@sub_num@} = {@ta@} \]

Therefore, using the table of reciprocals, the reciprocal of \({@a@}\) is {@ta@}.
